div.head: BIRTH
div.p: STUBBS- On the 27th November at zeitounm, the Wife of Maurice C. Stubbs of a son.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH.
div.p: Lord Cromer's speech at the Unionist Free Trade Club is reported at length in "The times." In another column we give a representatice selection of extracts from the leading home newspapers on the speech. The following home newspaper on the speech. The following extract from the speech os local interest as dealing with Egypt and the Sudan:-

"Let me give you an illustration based on my own experience of the wisdom of allowing free trade to form the basis of an Imperial policy. When some few years ago, the military genius of my friend Lord Kitchener rescued the Sudan from barbarism the question arose as the how, tor the future, the country should be governed. It had been conquered party by Britsih and partly by Egyptian men and money. There were strong objections to simply incorporating the newly-acquired country into Egyptian territory. Had this been done all the cumbersome international institutions which have so greatly hampered progress in Egypt would have come into force in a country singularly unsuited for experiments of this nature. On the other hand, the british Governmemt had neither the right nore the wish to annex the country. A compromise was therefore found. The sudan is now neither Britsih nor Egyptian; it is Anglo-Egyptian. Both the Bristish and Egyptian flags fly over the residence of Sir Reginald Wingate at Khartoon. Foreign Governments had they been so minded, might have taken exception to the creation of a status hydrid political hithertowholly unkown to international jurists. But not a murmur was heard. Why was this? It was because a special clause was inserted in the Convention regulating the future government of the Sudan to the effect that no preference should be given to responsible for this Convention, hall-marked as it was with the free-trade imprimatur. The miniser who sanctioned and warmly aproved this arrangement was one whose sound Imperialism cannot, I conceive, be called in question. It was the late Lord Salisbury. Let me add that, so far as be at present gathered, British trade has not suffered by the absence of any right to preferential treatment in the Sudan. It has held its own well.

But I think I can give another and even more striking illustration of the politcial advantahes to be derived from a free-trade policy. Consider for a moment the very anomalous position that until three years ago was occupied by the British Government in Egypt. It was one which rendered us singularly liable to the display of hostility on the part of foreign Powers. We have at times had to encounter that hostility, but it merely took the form of embarrasing our action in local and adminstrative matters. There was never any serious desire enviced by the Powers of Europe collectively to get us out of the country. Eventually our position was regularized by the Anglo- French Agreement, under the auspices of Lord Lansdowne, an arrangement which was not merely of great local importance, but also removed a source of constant European disquietude, That agreement could not come into force until it had been accepted by all the Powerd of Europe. It was readily obtained. Does any one believe that we should have been able to obtain general European acceptance if If so, I venture to assert that inquiries made at Berlin, and perphaps in other capitals of Europe, would him to modify his opinion One of the main reasons why, in spite of the difficulties of the situation, we have been able to do a good piece of work in Egyopt, and why we have enventually been able to get Europe to acquiesce in our continuance of that work, has been that, during the whole course of the ocupation, the principles of free trade have been rigidly applied in that country. Once depart from those principles, and I am convinced, that our occupation of Egypt will be regarded in a very different light from that in which it is not viewed. In fact, this question of comercial policy exercises a predominating influence on almost every question which can be raised in connexion with our external relations.

div.head: The Mariout Post.
div.p: An office for correspondence, parcels and money orders, has been opened at Dabaa on the Alexandria-Mariout line.

div.head: Hashiah Selzure.
div.p: A Jew named Haim Israiel has been arrested at Cairo station where he was attempting to dispatch nearly twelve kilos of hashish by train.

div.head: The Boulac Bridge.
div.p: Tenders for the proposed Boulac bridge will probably be dealt with during the course of next month, and building commenced early in the new year.

div.head: Government Lands.
div.p: Some local newspapers have of late give publicity to a rumour that the Government lands are to be sold, or rather that Sir E. Gorst might permit them to be sold. The information is a pure invention.

div.head: Hellenic Colony in Calro.
div.p: The census taking of the Hellenic Colony in Cairo will be completed in the course of this week. It is surmised that the colony numbers about 25,000 souls although the census may not give more than 20,000 owing to absences.

div.head: Hedjaz Rallway.
div.p: The Financial Administration of the Hedjaz Railway received contributions amounting to ps. 100,568 during the month of September, the subscribers being officers of the Imperial Army and Mahomedan residents in Bosnia and Rumania.

div.head: Egypt's Debt to Lord Cromer.
div.p: The prosperity of Egypt under Lord Cromer is an undeniable fact. In twenty-five years he succeeded in making of Egypt a modern country. The only dark side in this brilliant situation is the ancestral ignorance of the natives -"Dentsche Rundschau," Berlin.

div.head: Births and Deaths.
div.p: 345 deaths, of which 14 were Europeans, and 150 children under the age of five years, are recorded in Cairo for the week ending 25th November, and for the same period there are 13 European and 589 native births recorded. Ten deaths were due to diphtheria and five to typhus.

div.head: Egyptian State Domain Bonds.
div.p: Messrs. N. M. Rothschild and Sons announce that Egyptian State Domain Mortgage Bonds to the amount of £15,980 nominal capital have been drawn for payment at par on December 2. The drawing consists of all bonds (not previously cancelled by the operation of the sinking fund) comprised in the series of numbers advertised.

div.head: Supreme Consular Court.
div.p: The hearing of the civil case Scott Dalgleish versus Ades, which was before the Supreme British Consular Court yesterday, has been adjourned until Tuesday next for pleadings. The case against a lady who is accused of forging a signature involving the payment of L.E. 250 was up for hearing yesterday morning but was not concluded.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: On Monday the Lilliputian troupe of artistes will make their debut at the Alhambra theatre, Alexandria, in the "Geisha." This troupe, which has met with great success in Cairo, is composed entirely of children, who both individually and collectively give performances which are well worthy of comparison with those of the more experienced troupes which visit Egypt.

div.head: Towns and Buildings Dept.
div.p: It appears that the numbers of employés whom it has been stated are to be discharged from the Towns and Buildings Department of the P.W.D. have been exaggerated. None of the permanent staff are, we understand, to be dispensed with, but the credit for building purposes being reduced this year, the temporary staff, which it must be borne in mind invariably fluctuates according to the amount of work which has to be perforined each year, will in consequence be reduced.

div.head: CHRISTMAS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The continued growth of Egypt as a winter resort is evidenced by the ever-increasing flow of visitors. The bookings this season by the steamers are, indeed, the heaviest on record, and many berths are already being reserved for the Christmas tours.

The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company is organising a special tour, starting from Charing-cross at 9 a.m, December 20. The steamer will travel over the Mediterranean, via Marseilles to Alexandria,and visitors may return on January 9, arriving in London four days afterwards, or they may prolong their stay many weeks, special facilities being provided for trips into the desert, sailing up the Nile &c.

div.head:
A. S. C.
NOTICE
div.p: A small silver watch bearing the name E. Dudley Hanly has been found on the Sporting Club grounds and may be recovered on application being made to the Secretary, 6 Boulevard de Ramleh.

div.p: RIDING BREECHES. F.Phillips & Co. LADIES' TAILORS.
(HIGH CLASS WORK ONLY) CAIRO & ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: MARY KINGSLEY MEDAL. AWARDED TO MR. CHAMBERLAIN
div.p: The Right Hon. Joseph Chamberlain has been presented with the Mary Kingsley Medal by the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine for his services in the cause of the amelioration of health conditions in the tropics.

div.head: KAID MACLEAN. RAISULI COMES TO TERMS.
div.p: It is expected that Kaid Maclean will be released in a few days, Raisuli having agreed to the terms proposed.

div.head: GALATA FUNICULAR RAILWAY. PURCHASED BY GERMAN CO.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph” states that the German-Constantinople Tramway Company has purchased the English company which constructed and worked the underground funicular railway from Galata to Pera.

div.head: THE "AMENDE HONORABLE.”
div.p: Mr. Edalji has just been reinstated as a solicitor, he having been struck off the rolls on his conviction in regard to the Great Wyrley cattle maiming outrages.

div.head: BUDGET FOR 1908
div.p: The receipts for the year 1908 are estimated at L.E. 15,030,000, against an expenditure of L.E. 14,730,000, leaving a surplus L.E. 300,000.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY BUDGET. ESTIMATES FOR 1908. CONSTRUCTED PROPERTY TAX.
div.p: The receipts for the year 1907 from the constructed property tax including the additional centime are calculated at L.E. 91,000 against a tax of L.E. 95,900, so that an income from this source of L.E. 90,000 in 1908 is certain
Tenant's 2% Tax.

The tax for the year 1907 has been L.E. 25,300 and the receipts are calculated at L.E. 23,000. Although a diminution in rents is not probable next year, the estimate for 1908 has been reduced to L.E. 22,000.
Receipts from the Abbatoir.
The estimated receipts for 1908 from the Abbatoir are L.E. 36,000, i.e. L.E. 4,000 more than in the present year.
Rights to Pathways.
During 1907 the receipts from the rights to occupy public ways are calculated to be L.E. 10,500, and in the budget for 1908 the same has been estimated at L.E. 10,400.
Various Receipts.

The following receipts are estimated from various sources :-Difference on land rent at Bab Sidra, L.E. 1,538; Difference in lavatory receipts, sale of wood, fruit, etc. L.E. 312; Difference in payment towards fire brigade by the theatres L.E. 150 ; giving a total of L.E. 2,000.
Provision Fund.
A further sum of L.E. 300 is estimated as receipts from payments during 1906 by those of the staff depositing money for the "fonds de prévoyance."
Interest on Unengaged Monies.

The estimate of receipts in 1908 from this source is L.E. 12,000, of which L.E. 7,700 from the purchasers of quay property and L.E. 4,300 from sums deposited at the Ministry of Finance and the various banks of the town.
Carting.

A considerable decrease in receipts from carting is allowed for, those in 1907 being L.E. 17,280, whereas for 1908 only LE. 14,000 is estimated, the chief reasons being the economic situation of the country and the replacing of stone for building purposes by bricks.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S.S. "City of Dundee" of the Westcott Lawrance Line left Malta last night and is due here next Sunday with general cargo from London.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK
div.p: Mr. H.A. Richardson presided at the annual general meeting of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank (Ltd.), on Tuesday week at 27, Clements lane, E.C.

In moving the adoption of the report, which recommended a dividend of 15 per cent, the chairman said the balance-sheet showed a considerable reduction in businesg, due, of course, to the crisis through which Egypt had been passing, but it also showed a considerable addition of strength which was of a highly satisfactory nature having regard to the present troubles across the Atlantic and their possible consequences. The bills payable showed a reduction of £700,000, and deposits and other accounts £550,000. The year had been an exceptionally good one, and they had therefore been able to provide fully for the somewhat exceptional losses on all bad and doubtful debts out of the year's revenue. The gross profits were about £13,000 more than last year, and the net profits were only £3,000 more. The past year had been a memorable one. First and foremost there was a bumperi cotton crop of nearly seven millions of cantars, or a million more than the previous year's crop, and it was all sold at unusually high prices. The rush to secure cotton at the beginning of the season caused quite an unprecedented demand for sovereigns and coming with an American demand for gold, helped to disturb the London money market. £10,274,000 were imported into Egypt during the year, of which sum £4,500,000 were re-exported and £5,700,000 remained in the country, against an average of £3,000,000 in previous prosperous years. But alongside so much material prosperity the speculation which had been going on for two or three years in land and shares gathered force. Urban and suburban land and buildings changed hands at everincreasing prices ; new companies were formed to buy them, and the shares were engineered to a premium and placed for the most part with weak speculators on borrowed money, not, of course, from the banks, but from private people, tempted ty the high rates of contango offered. But the pace became too hot to last; the bubble burst and the inevitable crash came in the spring. Then paper fortunes disappeared as quickly as they had been made. There was also special trouble with Cairo and Manchester firms who had been largely financing their import business by bills drawn in Egypt on their home cerrespondents, who found that owing to the dislocation of credit they were unable to renew them. There fore many otherwise probably quite solvent firms were brought down and the import business practically stopped. It was hoped that this lesson would be conducted in futore orró sounder financial basis. The export houses and merchants in general had stood aloof from all these speculations, and the banks had persistent ly refused to encourage the movement, the loss for the most part falling on the smaller traders and private people. There must still be some wreckage to be cleared away, and no doubt some buyers of properties would be unable to find money to pay for their purchases, while complications would arise amongst the inters mediate buyers and sellers on the instalment system. But all this could not destroy, although it might retard the progress of the country, which had already shown distinct signs of recovery, and a good start had been made for the current year. There was another excellent cotton crop, valued at some £23,000,000, and it was estimated that one half had been already sold. He might observe that the Nile this year had been the worst on record, ard if the cotton crop of 1908 was & success instead of a failure it wonld be entirely due to the foresight of the Egyptian Governinent and the new dams which they had built. Although Egypt had got this good start it had to reckon with the American crisis, which threatened to upset the business as wel: as the money markets of the world. Already its effect was being felt in dear money and restrictions to European credits in Egypt, and naturally there had been a check to the activity in the cotton market.
Mr. T. Usborne seconded the motion, which was carried unanimously.

div.head: UNITED HOTELS OF EGYPT LTD.
div.p: A London contemporary in announcing that this company has decided upon dissolution, with reimbursement of 6s, out of the 108. paid on each shave, draws attention to the magpanimity of Baron de Kusel Bey in the following terms: "Our particular attention has been called to the magninimous action of Baron de Kusel, who, of his own motion, renounced all benefit from the contract entered into between him and the company on February 27 last, whereby he was to be appointed managing director for five years on a salary."
A French version of this action proceeds : "On nous signale tout particulièrement le geste noble du baron de Kusel, qui a, de propos délibéré, etc."

div.head: EGYPTIAN ESTATES
div.p: The announcement that the Egyptian Estates, Limited, does not propose to pay an interim dividend on the Ordinary shares this year, although disappointing, will hardly come as a surprise to the proprietors says the "Financial Times”. A year ago a dividend of 1s. per share was declared, but that proved the final distribution, for although the accounts—made up to the 6th April last—showed a surplus of £76,600, the Directors decided, in view of the financial stringency prevailing, to carry the whole of this balance forward. At the annual meeting the Chairman, alluding to the difficulties which had been encountered, said that, notwithstanding the general prosperity of the country, money was so scarce that it was difficult to borrow even on the very best security, and therefore for the present they would have to utilise all their available funds for current requirements. These, he added, were sufficiently enormous, and would continue so during the greater part of the current year, and financial conditions have not altered very greatly for the better since then.

div.head: ANGLO-BELGIAN COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: The report of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt, Limited, for the period of nearly seventeen months ended July 81 last, to be submitted at the meeting on the 28th inst., states that 69,668 shares of £5 each have been subscribed for out of a total authorised capital of £200,000. The shares were issued at a premium of 6s. per share, and the proceeds of such premium have been deducted from the preliminary expenses account in accordance with the terms of the prospectus. The company's investment in the Fayoum Light Railways Company, in which concern this company has the controlling interest, has been valued at cost. The sum of £7,044 interest of the company's Fayoum investment in respect of the years 1904-5 has been appropriated to write down preliminary expenses. The directors at first considered whether this amount should be credited to profit and loss, but, acting upon the opinion of the company's legal advisers, they decided to adopt the safer policy of appropriating the amount in the above-mentioned manner. It is proposed to carry forward the profit of £2,311.

div.head: IMPORTANT SALE.
div.p: Luzatto Pasha, manager of the Bank of Egypt, has just bought, for the sum of L.E. 39,200, half of a large block of houses at Alexandria, facing the Savoy Palace Hotel, on the Rosetta Boulevard, which is the aristocratic quarter of the city. The entire block covers an area of 6,150 square pics (about 4,134 square yards), and his Excellency is now owner of the whole, having bought the other half in February last from the Aghion family

div.head: PORTS AND LIGHTS ADMINISTRATION. CASES OF CORRUPTION.
div.p: The Finance Ministry has published official notices of the dismissal of two of the officials of the Ports and Lights Administration, who have been found guilty of having been implicated in the scandals, the revelation of which has so greatly shocked public opinion in Egypt. The Ministry announces that a special council, which was convened on the 18th inst., has confirmed the decision of the Council of Discipline of the Ports and Lights Administration, which decided that Socrates Spiro Bey, the Director of the Administrative Service of that Administration, should be considered as having been dismissed from the 1st September last for having been found guilty of irregularities and very grave faults in the fulfilment of his official duties. The Ministry also agreed with the council in condemning this high official to the total loss of the pension, which he was entitled to on his retirement from the service of the Government.

The Ministry of Finance has also confirmed the finding of the Council of Discipline, which dismissed Mr. Francesco Esposito, Director of the Carpentering Department of the Ports and Lights Administration, for having been implicated in the scandals. He is to lose all rights to a pension.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE. AN ENGLISHMAN ATTACKED.
div.p: The latest victim to bubonic plague is an English inspector of the Egyptian State Railway Stores at Gabbary. The patient was removed to hospital on Tuesday, and is now lying there serionsly ill.

div.head: SUSPECTED PLAGUE CASES.
div.p: The "Anchor" liner "Olympia" (Captain Osborne R.N.R.) arrived at Suez this afternoon from Bombay, and the ship's doctor declared to the Quarantine authorities that a lascar died yesterday on board after 4 days sickness and was buried at sea. But as the symptoms of the sickness were those of bubonic plague, the steamer is now being disinfected by the Quarantine authorities, and will enter the Canal in strict quarantine this evening. Some deck passengers who landed here were sent to Moses Wells to perform 5 days' quarantine.

The Quarantine medical officer, while examining the crew of the Italian mail boat "Raffaele Rubattino," which arrived at Suez yesterday morning, discovered a suspected case of bubonic plague among the lascars, which was subsequently landed and conveyed to Moses Wells for treatment. After a thorough disinfection of the crew's effects and quarters, the steamer was allowed to enter the Canal in free pratique towards the evening.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SPEECH. HOME PRESS OPINION
div.p: Below we give a few excerpts from the presi comments on Lord Cromer's entry into politica life at home.
TIMES

It is a pity that Lord Cromer, whose entry into the field of home politics we desire to welcome, did not follow the chairman's lead, instead of taking the position of Mr. Balfour and reasonable tariff reformers generally from the statements of their opponents Having begun by treating Mr. Balfour as a protec tionist, and by applying to tariff reformn the nickname of protection affixed to it for obvious, if not very worthy, reasons by the opponents of the Unionist party, Lord Cromer ended naturally enough by declaring that there is no | way to union except by putting protectionmeaning tariff reform-on the shelf. It is difficult to imagine how an eminently practical statesman could fail to perceive that this is impossible. Mr. Balfour cannot put tarifi reform on the shelf even if he desired to do 80, nor can the Unionist party pat it on the shelf. Nothing can be gained by offering impossible | advice, but for those who have been trying to preach toleration to tariff reformers it is rather discouraging to find that they are required by the other side to stop at nothing short of | unconditional surrender. Whatever else it may | do or fail to do, that attitude on the part of Unionist free-traders certainly does not make for comprehension and unity.
"MANCHESTER GUARDIAN."

Lord Cromer's is the typically English type of administrative mind which deals with facts | as they come along, and slowly builds up a | theory to fit them. Lord Milner's is the opposite type of mind, which begins with a theory | and makes it a Procrustean bed on which facts are laid out and hacked about to fit it. Lord Milner is strong on Protection because it fits in so comfortably with the discredited theory of colonial policy which he alone among Conservatives has had neither the grace nor the tact to abandon. Lord Cromer, we dare say, | would not mind if he could come to the orthodox party view on Protection, but he is saved by his wholesome respeot for the faets | as he knows them, and remains, as he called himself last night, & "convinced and unrepentant Pree-trader.”
"TRIBUNE."

Lord Cromer speaks on the fiscal, question with twofold weight, as a great financier and as an expert upon this country's foreign relations. He dwelt last night at the Unionist Free Trade Clab banquet on this aspect of Tariff Reform-an immensely important one, though it is apt to be subordinated to the domestio and "Imperial” aspects. There can be no doubt that one of the great evils of this policy is that it would inevitably make jealous ill-will against our world-wide Empire a very real factor in international feeling, and create intense friction at every point. Lord Cromer does not hesitate to say, from inside knowledge, that dnly as a Free Trade nation could we have induced the Powers to recognize our position in Egypt. For that and other reasons he demands that Tariff Reform sball be "definitely laid on the shelt.” It will be interesting to see whether this and the Duke of Devonshire's pathetic protest against Unionist adherence to Tariff Reform will produce any sign from M. Balfour.
"Pall Mall GAZETTE."

We had rather, on the whole, that Lord Cromer had not fitted on to his great proconsular career the anti-climax of a scramble in those miry fields of party politics where he is fettered by all the drawbacks of the amateur who makes a beginning late in life. But, on the other hand, uniting, as we do, a great respect for Lord Cromer with a firm belief in the necessity for Fiscal Reform, we cannot but rejoice that from the lips of the one there should come so little that need interfere with our attachment to the other. For Lord Cromer's speech is, above all else, a remarkable disclosure of the straits to which a statesman of high calibre is pressed in order to construct an argument in defence of Cobdenism as an | Imperial policy. The new vice-president of the Unionist Free Trade Club felt the need of discrimination amongst the weapons which are kept in the armoury of that organization. He "put on one side the purely economic aspects of the question," and preferred to deal with the influence of Free Trade upon our international relations.
"GLOBE."

The most interesting, but by no means the most convincing, part of Lord Cromer's speech was that in which he declared thst it was only the existence of absolute Free Trade as the pole star of British policy which rendered possible the occupation of Egypt and the acquiescence of Europe in the recovery of the Sudan and the Anglo-French agreement. We confess that we do not quite follow him. In the first place, Egypt does not belong to England, and never has done, and it would have been out of our power, even had we desired it, to impose a preferential tariff in favour of ourselves. And in the second place, it had always been our impression that the strieken field of Omdurman, the existence in full efficiency of the British Navy, and the peacefal diplomacy King Edward were the main agents which enabled Lord Cromer by successive steps to reconoile Europe to our presence in the land of the Pharaohs. Nor did we think it a very convincing argument that if we adopted Tariff Reform we must be prepared to encounter the permanent hostility of foreign nations, and to face the necessity of increasing our expenditure on the Army and Navy.
"WESTMINSTER GAZETTH."

Lord Cromer's speech at the Unionist Free Trade Club last night is sufficiently impartial in its advice to both parties to enable us to express our satisfaction with the chiet part of it without being supposed to hail him as a Daniel come to judgmebit in our own cause. It is extremely important that the Imperial Jaspect of Free Trade, on which he enlarged 88 out of his long and eminent experience, should al | be brought home to the British people. What is it which has enabled us to maintain our political ascendenoy in so many parts of the y world with so comparatively little friction and co jealousy from our neighbours and rivals 1 It is, he answers withont hesitation, the rule or ir perfect equality in trade which we have n applied wherever we are able to control policy. g|That has helped us in Egypt, helped us in the > Sudar, helped us in India, in the Far East, e and wherever else there has been a question o 3, of extending our | Tule. We cannot flatter s ourselves that our successes in this respect I have at the outset been welcomed with any o particular foryour in Europe, or that we, i as - a race, have, apart from our policy, any special B gift for conciliating other races. But our role 1 | is found in practice to be unattended with the s friotion and jealousy which are set up when it the traders of other nations find themselves excluded by the Power in possession.

div.head: A LAND DISPUTE.
div.p: In the early hours of yesterday morning a fierce fight, which resulted in several persons receiving severe injuries, took place between the men of Count Zizinia and those of Abdel Latif Effendi Gawish, a French subject, and Youssef Effendi Najin. The fight was the result of a dispute concerning land adjoining the Nouzha Gardens which was awarded by the court of the Mixed Tribunals to Count Zizinia. The question of possession, however, was still disputed by the defendants and on his return Count Zizinia found that Gawish was flying a French flag over a kiosk on the ground. On complaining to the Greek Consul he was referred to the French Consul and by the latter to the police authorities. From this point, however, the Count appears to have taken the law into his own hands and on the night in question armed about 20 of his men whom he sent to the plot of land with a Greek flag. It was not long after their arrival that the fight commenced and not only were nabouts used but also shots exchanged. The mounted police were soon on the scene of the fray and after some trouble succeeded in quelling the disturbances and effected several arrests, among whom was Count Zininia. The Count, however, was liberated and a complaint lodged against him at the Greek Consulate. Abdel Latif Effendi Gawish was seriously wounded and five men of the fighting parties also received injuries more or less severe, while four policemen were slightly injured.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince George William, son of the Duke of Cumberland, who arrived at Alexandria by the N.D.L. steamer, has proceeded to Cairo.
Prince Fouad Pasha and Mustapha Pasha Ibadi have arrived here from Cairo.

It is now settled that the wedding between Lady Ruby Elliot, daughter of the Viceroy of India and Lady Minto, to Lord Cromer's eldest son, Lord Brrington, will take place in April in England. Lady Ruby is to join her parents in India this winter, and accompanies them on their Burmah tour, proceeding to England early in February. Lady Minto goes to England by a later boat, arriving in England in the second week of April, in company with her youngest daughter, Lady Violet Elliot..

Sir William Garstin, whose resignation will date from March next, will in all probability be replaced by Mr. Webb, and Mr. Dupuis will be appointed Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of Public Works.

M. Nicolas Sursock of Alexandria, gave a dinner party last week in the restaurant of the Hotel Ritz, Paris, at which were present among others : Duc and Duchesse de Camastra, Marquez and Margueza Bourbon del Monte, Marquis and Marquise Oietta, Prince Bondini, M. de Masséno, and Mme. and Mlle Sursock.
It is stated that Sir Horace Pinehing, late Director General of the Public Health Department, will be granted a pension of L.E. 500 per annum.
Sanieh Hanem, Kamer Hanem, and Wagel Hanem, ladies-in9waiting to the Khediyah0mother, have been decorated by the Sultan with the Shafakat order.
Mr. P. Manson has returned to Cairo from Upper Egypt

Among those who left Suez yerterday after-by the Khedivial Mail S.S. "El Kahira" for Port Sudan were Mr. W. Harvey and Mr. W. M. Scott, of the Ministry of Public Works, and Mr. L. Deperais, the Suez agent of the Florio-Rubattino line, who is proceeding to the Red Sea to establish agencies on behalf of the company for their monthly services, which commence early next month.

div.head: TRIBUNAL MIXTE DU CAIRE
div.p: Audience du 25 novembre, 2e Chambre Civile.

En 1881, M. Carlo Sechino avait emprunte au Crédit Foncier Egyptien une somme de 800 livres en garantie de laquelle il avait remis trois polices d'assurance sur la vie s'élevant au chiffre de 65.000 frs.

En 1906, le Crédit Foncier assignait donc M. Sechino et sa femme pour voir réaliser les polices d'assurance et être remboursé, capital et intérêts. L'affaire, renvoyée à diverses reprises, venait à l'audience d'hier pour être plaidée. Avant toute plaidoirie, Me Manusardi, pour les époux Sechino, soulevait deux exceptions, l'une de nullité de l'acte introductit d'instance, et l'autre d'incompétence. Mais le tribunal ayant rejeté ces deux exceptions, Me Manusardi a du plaider le fond.

En 1891, donc, M. Sechino concluait un acte de prêt de 800 L. avec le Crédit Foncier, donnant en nantissement ses trois polices d'assurance de 65.000 francs. Mme de Grossi, son épouse, autorisée par le consulat d'Italie, intervint à cette convention. A l'échéance, M. Sechino ne pouvant rembourser le Crédit Foncier, par une seconde convention, lui accorda une prolongation. Mais il faut dès maintenant mettre Mme de Grossi hors de cause, car elle avait bien une autorisation pour intervenir à la convention de 1891, mais elle n'en avait pas pour la seconde. Et Me Manusardi insiste à nouveau sur la nullité de l'exploit introductif de mai 1906, car il indique la prescription de 15 ans. Si la prescription est rejetée, la somme de 1157 L. que réclame le Crédit Foncier est, en tous cas, exagérée. Il y a 800 L. en principal. Mais les intérêts, qui devaient être comptés à 7% l'an, n'ont jamais été réclamés depuis 1891, or, pour les intérêts, la prescription est de 5 ans ; ce ne sont pas, par conséquent, les intérêts depuis 1891 qu'il faut réclamer, mais seulement ceux des cinq dernières années. Le Crédit Foncier demande encore le remboursement de diverses primes qu'il a payées, pour le compte de M. Sechino, à la Compagnie d'Assurance. Mais M. Sechino aussi en a payé. Il faut vérifier ces comptes.
Me Chalom, pour pouvoir communiquer les reçus de la Compagnie d'Assurance à son honorable confrère, demande le renvoi, à huitaine, de la continuation des débats.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE.
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi)

Les nouvelles plus rassurantes arrivées du dehors ont occasionné un retour de confiance dans la corbeille. Les vendeurs se tenant sur la réserve le groupe haussier a eu beau jeu pour pousser les cours. Aussi, bien que les affaires soient restées en somme limitées, on a constaté un relèvement presque général de la cote. L'attention s'est principalement concentrée sur les valeurs dirigeantes et les titres secondaires fa voris de la spéculation, mais sans que tout cela ait rien offert de bien saillant

La National Bank progresse de 20 à 20 1/8,la Ramleh de 4 1/4 8 4 3/8, la Delta Light de 9 11/16 a' 9 3/4, les Tramways d'Alexandrie | de 135 à 140 les Privilégiées et de 261 à 270 les Dividendes, la Daïra de 12 5/16 à 12 7/16, l'Obligation nouvelle Crédit Foncier de 252 à 254, la Banque d'Athènes de 110 à 110 1/2, l'Union Foncière de 4 1/4 à 4 5/16, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 4 4 1/16, et la Banque d'Orient de 113 à 114.
Les aotions de Capital Eaux dn Caire continuent, au contraire, à Aéchir de 108 à 105, les Nungovich Hotels de 16 1/2 à 15 1/4, et les Splendid do. 4 3/16 à 4 1/8.

En titres d'ordre secondaire, les Markets rétrogradent de 25|- à 24/6, la Spinning de 9/32 à 1/4, la Salt & Soda de 14/6 à 14/- et l'Action Allotment de 2 à 1 7/8, tandis que la Delta Land remonte de 1 1/8 à 17/32, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 20/6 à 21/-, les Estates de 3/8 à 13/32, le Comptoir de 2 15/32 à 2 1/2 l'action et de 1 3/8 à 17/16 la fondateur, la Building Lands de 1 1 2 à 1 9/16, la Port Said Salt de 11/9 à 12]- et l'United de 7/32 à 1/4.

La reprise qu'on a pu remarquer depuis quelques jours en Ramleh est attribuée à l'annonce d'un excellent coupon. La Delta Land a été vigoureusement poussée, sans beaucoup d'affaires, ainsi que la National Bank. *Pour le moment la tendance est bonne.

Relativement à notre entrefilet d'hier sur le conflit existant entre la Hooker et l'Helouan, nous devons spécifier que S.E. Mohsen Pacha n'a pas traité avec le groupe Rossano. Celui ci a acheté directement de la Hooker.

Ont été exécutés ce matin per voie d'en-| chères publiques, à la requête de Cesana & Cie, MM. Isaac Dib et Jean Stefas. Pour le premier il a été vendu 25 Splendid Hotels à 4 1/32, 100 actions anciennes New Egyptian à 9/11 et 50 nouvelles à 9/-, 50 Banque d'Athènes à 110 3/4, 25 Salt & Soda à 15/– 25 Estates à 27/64, 100 Cotton Mills à 1/- 50 Port Said Salt à 12/1), 50 Levant à 17/32, 100 Spinning à 17/64, 25 actions Allotment à 57/64 et 50 fondateurs à P.T. 38, 50 Ordinary Khedivial Mail à 20/6, 25 Delta Land à 1 9/82, 25 Crédit | Franco-Egyptien à 4' 1/16 et 5 fondateurs United à 9/16. Et pour le second, 75 General Trust (Hooker) à 7/32, 25 Estates & 13/32, 20 Building Lands à 1 9/16, 25 Delta Land a 15/64, et 2 actions nouvelles Salt & Soda à 14/6.

On dit que le projet d'une Banque exclusivement indigène tant par les administrateurs qué par les capitaux, paralt devoir se réaliser. Le capital initial serait de 5 millions de livres | fi égyptiennes. Les opérations de la Banque seraient celles de tous les autres établissements d similaires.
Quatre assemblées générales de socistés égyptiennes doivent avoir lieu aujourd'hui, deux au Caire et les deux autres à Londres. Ce sont celles :
1. De la Société Foncière du Domaine de Cheikh-Fadl, dont les actionnaires doivent se réunir à 4 h. p.m. au siège social, au Caire.
2. Des United Hotels of Egypt qui ont invité leurs actionnaires à une assemblée générale extraordinaire devant être tenue à 4 h. p.m. au siège, 21, rue Emad-el-Dine.
3. De l'Anglo-Belgian Cy., dont les actionnaires tiendront une assemblée extraordinaire au siège social de Londres, 62, London Wall E.C.

4. De The Egyptian Land Investment Cy qui ont une assemblée générale extraordinaire pour la répartition de l'actif liquide de la Société à concurrence du 25 % du capital social, par la distribution immédiate de P.T. 125 par action.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries and Bontigny Ltd.
NOTES ET CRITIQURS -
div.p: Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres est renseigné en baisse de 1/4 à 6 1/2 pour cent.

Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté hier in varie à 82 1/4. L'Unifiée a été ferme à 99. LaNational Bank a été soutenue | à 19 3/4, la Daïra à 12 3/8 et l'Agricole à 7 5.8. La Delta Light a progressé de 1/8 à 9 7/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien s'est e maintenu à 681 et la Banque d'Athènes à 109. Les Lots turcs ont gagné 1 franc à 164. -

Ici, le ton général du marché a été aujour|d'hui beaucoup plus réconfortant vu la baisse | du taux de l'escompte libre à Londres et la certitude qu'il ne saurait que s'améliorer encore par la suite. La détente monétaire aux EtatsUnis s'affirme de plus en plus et la fermeté de nos valeurs au Stock Exchange est un indice | point à dédaigner ; leurs cours d'ailleurs ne pourront que se relever dès que le capitaliste anglais aura de nouveau avartage à s'occuper | de ces titres. **

Certes, part quelques titres outragensei ment dépréciés ces derniers jonrs, et qui commencent déjà à reconquérir une partie du terrain perdu, les transactions n'ont pas été ce que le vondrait la saison, mais la séance a fait preuve d'activité et d'un peu moins de pessimisme.

Sans aucun doute si les liquidations ne pesaient pas continuellement sur la plupart des valeurs, ce qui éloigne beaucoup d'acheteurs, nous serions actuellement en plein renouveau | financier. Comme l'amélioration ne peut que | persister, soit en Amérique, soit en Europe, il | serait temps pour ceux dont les dossiers sont formés de titres achetés aux anciens cours, de | les compléter puisque la baisse s'est exercée à son soul sur tous les titres. Abaissant lear | moyenne d'achat, ils assureraient leurs béné. fices pour le commencement de la reprise iné. vitable, et pourraient ainsi plus rapideinent se créer des disponibilités, n'étant pas obligés | d'attendre que les cours soient parvenus au plus haut.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la Na. tional Bank hausse à 20 1/8 en gain de 5/16 L'Agricole est mieux disposée 7 3/4-13/16. La Banque d'Athènes ayance à 108-109 et la Banque d'Orient à 113-114. La Cassa di Sconto revient à 42. Les H. de Vries and Boutigny Ltd. se relèvent à 0 5/16-3/8.

La Delta Light est plus soutenue à 9 11/163/4 ainsi que la Ramleh Railways à 4 5/16. L'action Capital Eaux du Caire tombe à 100 alors que les Jouissances haussent do 8 franesc # 183. Le Crédit Foncier Egyptien est en pro-IR grès à 676, ainsi que la Béhéra privilégiée à 4 1/8. La Wardan Estates perd 11/16 à 3 1/4. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux, très In actives, se relèvent à 0 7/8 et leur part à P.T. | G. 16. L'Epargne Immobilière est également un peu mieux tenue à 0 3/4 et sa part à P.T. 12. G. Les Omnibus-Automobiles sont rainenés à Be 2 1/16.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich sont plus faibles à 15. Les Egyptian Hotels " (Baehler) sont en reprise à 4 5/8. Les Upper Egypt reculent à 2 1/2-9/16 et les Ritz à la 05/16.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la New Egyptian est en légère avance à 9/3, les fondateurs Estates également à 2 1/8. Les Oasis (Western Egypt) sont en meilleure tendance à 0 3/8- | F. 7/16 et les Ordinary Khedivial Mail en recul G. à 20/

M. L. Luzzati, ancien ministre des Finances Mc d'Itálie, a proposé dernièrement la réunion d'une "contérence internationale pour mettre R. un terme à la guerre pour l'or" dont tous les J. journaux financiers européens s'occupent.

L'or, dit-il, ne manque pas, il y en a toutw. autant qu'avant la crise, mais la méfiance l'a Ch fait disparaitre. En présence de la solidarite Can des marchés, le but à atteindre, c'est d'arriver G. par une coopération sincère, à empêcher l'explosion des crises, ou en tout cas à en adoucir es eifets pernicieux.

Une conférence internationale dans laquelle Dir iégeraient les représentants des Trésoreries et Sté des banques d'émission aurait à examiner les A. moyens pratiques d'améliorer les instruments | P, 1 lont se servent les banques d'émission, en A. l'autres termes à suggérer les réformes plau- | Der ibles dans la constitution des grandes ins-P. itutions. Le second point consisterait à Ere tudier les avances d'or que les banques R. onrraient se faire entre elles, ainsi que M. e composition des portefeuilles or. On trang-| E, ormerait en institution permanente ce qui A, 1 été pratiqué à trois reprises par la Banque klir e France à l'égard du marché de Londres. | 18.
C'est un programme de solidarité bancaire Var ondiale, une sorte d'assurance mytuelle For entre l'explosion des crises et contre les maux 23 pi en résultent.
Carnet de l'actionnaire

MM. les actionnaires de la "Sogiété Générale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce" sont informés que sur décision du Conseil d'Ad-1 ministration il a été décidé d'appeler, 25% sar | les actions de Capital ancienne émission, soit francs 62,50 par titre. |
Les versements doivent être effeotués au | plus tard le 20 Décembre prechain.

div.p: 2,000 Moors on Monday attacked a French reconnaissance force of 300 men who were operating against the Beni Snassen tribesmen in the Kiss region. The French retreated into Algeria with 8 wounded. It is reported that a number of hitherto loyal tribes have decided to join the Beni Snassen tribe and that different places along the coast have been applied for reinforcements. The situation is described as critical.
(Reuter)

General Drude telegraphs that the Sultan's General, El Bagdadi, has been fighting for two days with Mulay Hafid's Lieutenant, Mulai Ragshid, near Rabat. The former has been defeated losing two guns. The losses are considerable on both sides. The Sultan's force sent inland from Mogador is meeting with serious resistance.
(Reuter)

The Mehallah of Bagdadi has had a two days' fight against the reinforced Chaouias. Mouley Rashid in consequence of the defection of Bagdadi has retired, abandoning two cannons. General Drude confirms the defeat of Bagdadi.
(Havas)
The Moors made another raid this morning attacking the Bab el Asah post. The result is yet unknown. Measures have been taken to protect the frontier.
(Havas)

In the Chamber of Deputies M. Simoponlo introduced the budget. The revenue for. 1908 is estimated at 130,308,429 drachmae and the expenditure at 126,001,887. It inclodes a credit of 2,500,000 on behalf of Greco-Bulgarian refugees who have settled in the new cities of Thessaly. The war estimates again included 4,500,000 for national defence and 667,000 for increase of the gendarmery. The surplus of 1906 was 4,500,000. The deficit of 1907 of about 1,000,000 will be covered by the previous surplus proving the financial soundness of the country.
M. Simopoulo emphatically denied that a large deficit was probable or that the Government contemplated contracting a loan.(Reuter) |

Mr. Jenkins, President of the Jenkins Trust, has been arrested for forgery. His two brothers, the President and Director of the Williamsburg Trust, have also been arrested. Mr. Maxwell, ex-President of Botough Bank, recently arrested on the charge of larceny and forgery and who was released on bail until Monday, conmitted suicide yesterday.(Reuter)

The mining broker, Mr. Louis Straus, committed suicide by swallowing cyanide of potassium as detectives entered his residence to arrest him on charge of forgery. It is estimated that 18 suicides have taken place in the United States traceable to the crisis. (Reuter)

The Reporter of the Naval estimates laments the state of anarchy existing in the Navy. The sailors, engineers, gunners, and administrators were animated, he said, by the most regrettable mutual hostility. The Navy had already fallen to the third rank and there was danger of lapsing into the fourth.
(Reuter)

Captain Smith of the Garrison Artillery | whilst escorting the district commissioner was killed and 30 native soldiers was killed or wounded, up country near the Cross River. There are no details of the occurrence. It is supposed that the trouble is connected with compulsory road making.
(Reuter)

The Duma has unanimously adopted the proposal to present a loyal address to the Tsar. The amendments insisting on the inclusion in the address of references to autocratic power were rejected.
(Reuter)
At the inquest on General Colville it was = proved that he was riding at an excessive speed. General Rawlinson was entirely exonerated.
(Reuter)
Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman has started for Biarritz.
(Reuter)
Five men have been killed and eleven injured owing to an explosion in a colliery at Whitehaven.
(Reuter)
1 200 persons have been drowned owing to ship wrecks during the recent storms in the Euxine Sea, including 110 who perished by the | foundering of the "Mahsoussehi” at Kaplan.
(Reuter)
The Sultan of Zanzibar has left for Monte Carlo.
(Reuter)
Lord Battersea is dead.

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET
div.p: The Money Market.

As a measure calculated to afford temporary relief, the issue by the United States Treasurer of fifty million dollars of Panama Bonds and one hundred million dollars of one-year Treasury certificates of indebtedness was welcomed | by the money market here. The continued withdrawal of gold for America in spite of the higher bank rate had caused no little uneasiness, not merely in consequence of the effect this drain was having upon our own reserve, but also because it was felt that the authorities in the States were relying too much upon this policy to obtain relief, rather than upon efforts to restore the confidence of the public. Therefore, it was hoped that Mr. Cortelyou's action would check to some extent these shipments of precious metal. This is what has actually happened, but the general opinion is that the respite will be of only short duration. The discount rates have already returned to the high level prevailing last week-end. While itis admit. ted that the present situation demands prompt measures, this creation of forcedcurrency is view. ed with little favour by the best people here, and it is realised that it is an expedient which is sure to cause trouble sooner or later. The authorities in America do not seem to be acting very wisely in their efforts to overcome their difficulties. It is as foolish as it is futile to abuse depositors, as both Mr. Roosevelt and Mr. Cortelyou have done, for keeping la a tight hold on their money. The public is well aware that the sole cause of the present crisis is the reckless gambling on the part of the Trusts and many of the banking concerns, la and depositors cannot be blamed for refusing to run any more risks and for keeping their funds locked up, pending some substantial assurance that the Government are determined to make such a crisis impossible in the future by eliminating the canges of the present trouble. The complete restoration of public confidence along these lines must necessarily take time, but the Government can do much towards attaining this desired end by prompt | ly introducing measures of reform as soon as Congress re-assembles. Meanwhile, we may expect a continuance of the hoarding, and pro | bably, of the importation of gold from England and the Continent.

Last week we mentioned that the Bank of France had refused to ship gold direct to | America, and we gave it as our opinion that this was owing to the fact that there is no National Bank in the States. It is now, stated Twith authority that the French Government's reply to the request for direct shipments was that they were quite prepared to put some gold on the American market, on condition that the operation was carried out with the American Government. It is understood that the latter was not inclined to act as guarantor, so that the French authorities naturally refused to take any risk that might attach to such shipments of metal.

The fall in our reserve this week is not so large as was anticipated, the Bank only having lost £1,700,000 on balance. The stock of coin and bullion is also only £1,400,000 lower, and the note circulation having contracted to the extent of over £200,000, the reduction in the reserve is limited to £1,197,915. The | total reserve is now £19,915,401, as compared with £21,364,247 in the corresponding week last year, and the proportion to liabilities is 38,78 per cent, as against 40.52 last week, and 40.32 in 1906.
Money is in active demand, and overnight advances realised 54 per cent. and upwards. Three months' discount bills are firm at about 68.
The quotation for bar gold is 77/11% per oz. standard. ma
Silver.

Buying orders on Chinese account caused a substantial rise in the price of silver in the early part of the week, the quotation for forward delivery being at one time 273. The market has since declined, however, owing to reselling operations on the part of China. Yesterday the price for forward delivery fell to 27 tu.d.
The Stock Markets, -

The announcement of the measures adopted by the United States Treasurer to relieve the money stringenoy imparted a tone of cheerfulness in all departments of the Stock Exchange at the beginning of the week. Prior to this | there was much nervousness, it being anticipat|ed in many quarters that the Bank rate would. be further raised to 8 per cent. on Monday. Afterwards an active business was done, and shares througbout the list showed a substantial recovery. The gilt-edged section smartly responded to the better influence, and other sections were not slow to follow suit.

The revival had only a short life, however, | and during the greater part of the week the tone has been, as formerly, dall and irregular. The retention of the Bank rate at 7 per cent. was a cheering point yesterday, and the tone was better, although business remained on a very small scale. \

On second thoughts dealers are little disposed to believe that America's financial salvation is to be found in Mr. Cortelyou's latest move, which, it is felt, can have no more than a passing effect. As pointed out above, the restoration of public confidence must eventually be the key which must unlock the hoards of gold, and cause then to return into circulation. The sooner this fact is realised, and the knowledge acted upon, the sooner luay we expect a return to normal conditions.
Consols.
Following on the news from New York, Consols were very firm, and advance to 82% for the account. Subsequently they fell away, but yesterday closed with a rise of to 82, ta
To-day Consols have given way to for the accoant.
Foroign Bonds.

Foreigners have been somewhat irregolar. Rassians have kept firm, and the Fours left off last night at 76, a rise of a point since Saturday. The Fives were quoted 86, at which they showed an advance of on the week.
To-day Russian bonds have again been active, and the fours have further advanced 1 and the last issue.
Japanese, after being steady, are now weak, and yesterday several issues lost * to .
Home Ralls.

The home railway market has again had a fairly satisfactory week. The shares opened very active on Monday, and renewed investment buying and bear covering caused prices to advance rapidly all-round. North Western went up 144, a rise of 37, and South Western gained 2 to 441, North Eastern 1), to 1357. Great Eastern 1%, to 714, Lancashire and Yorkshire 11, to 98, and South Eastern "A” 1+ to 33.

There was some profit-taking on the follow ing day, but the market received another | fillip on Wednesday on the publication of the list of traffic showing substantial increases in most cases, and the tone continued firm yesterday. Metropolitan District shares were an exception, these being affected by the circular issued by the Managing Director on the financial position of the Company, in which it is proposed to apply for power to issue £750,000 Prior Lien Debenture Stock. The price fell 12 to 9.
Home railway shores have today been irregular. Metropolitan District have further declined , and Great Western. 14. Great Eastern and North Eastern are 7 better."

American railway shares are in a helplegs condition, and there appears to be little pros. pect of any revival of interest in them on this side until there is a substantial improvement in the financial position in the States. On Monday, it is true, the tone was buoyant, on the publication of the details of the currency relief proposals, but this was only a passing spurt. Advances up to four dollars were marked in several cases, Unions being up , but during the remainder of the week the tone has been listless.
Americans are lower again today. Southern Preference have lost 6), Louisville 3, Baltimore 2 }, and Union Pacific Preference 2

div.head: THE FALL OF KHARTOUM. GLADSTONE AND GORDON.
div.p: The question as to how, Mr. Gladstone enjoy ed himself at the theatre on the evening wher he heard of the death of Gordon and the fall o Khartoum has again come up for discussio owing to Lady Dorothy Nevill's allusion ti it in her recently published autobiographics notes. Lady Dorothy says on this old subjec of reproach against Mr. Gladstone : — "As i matter of fact, by no possibility could Mr Gladstone have known that the very evening on which he was going to the Criterion, Gordor was being done to death in the far-off Sudan and whatever may have been his faults, callous ness or inhumanity was most certainly no numbered amongst them.” We are quite as sure as Lady Dorothy Nevill is says the "Spectator," that inhumanity or callousness was ntterly foreign to Mr. Gladstone's nature, but there is very good authority for saying that he did go to the theatre that night, - persuaded to do 80, we believe, for the very reason that he was deeply upset and worried by the report of Gordon's death, and it was thought that at the theatre his mind would be distracte:l. If this be so, he did not reflect what the world might say (there was no certain ty, after all, that it would say anything), and that is perhaps a sign in itself of his preoccupation. Other Ministers of the Crown, at all events, were at theatres on the same night, and escaped the malignant censure to which Lady Dorothy Nevill refers.

div.head: KHARTOUM CHURCH.
div.p: The committee of the English church at Khartoum, of which Sir Reginald Wingate, the Sirdar, is chairman, and Major P. R. Phipps, Khartoum, is honorary secretary, are issuing an appeal for funds to complete the building, and also for the clergy sustentation fund. They have published an attractive and well illustrated pamphlet, showing the exterior and interior of the proposed church, and giving the story of the undertaking up to the present. Regular services were started in 1899 at Omdurman in the British Officers' Club, a building that was once the house of the Mahdi. Since 1900, when the Government head-quarters were removed to Khartum, a room in the Governor's Palace has been lent for the purpose. The appeal for a permanent church was first made with Lord Cromer's approval, and the comparatively small response, together with the gifts made on the spot, seemed to justify the laying of the stone in 1904, a ceremony performed by Princess Henry of Battenberg. The site chosen is on the main avenue, close to the Gordon statue, and just south of the Palace gardens. A clergy house has been erected there, and plans for the church were made in 1906 by Mr. Weir Schultz, of Gray's Inn. The money already placed at the committee's disposal, including £1,000 given last year by the Comtesse de Noailles, is nearly exhausted, and £7,000 will be required to complete the building, apart from the campanile. The hon. treasurer in England is Mr. Alfred Dyke Acland, 186, Strand, W.C.

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN TALE
div.p: The following veracious anecdote, told at the expense of a relic-hunter, appears in a recent work on Egypt. An Arab wished to sell a set of tomb furniture to a European client, but he had neither tomb furniture, nor body to his hand. However, he heard of a Copt who lived in a lonely part, and who was possessed of, and prepared for a deal in, those articles. A visit was paid, and the Copt "had pots in plenty, but not a body worthy of the British Museum. Sinister thoughts laid hold of the Arab. To slay a Christian is a dangerous thing to do ; but need he, as one of the faithful, let that prey on his mind, should there be little chance of his being found out? The Copt stooped to examine his pots once more, and the Arab dealt him a blow on the back of his head. Seeing that his victim did not need a second, the Moslem stripped the body of its clothes and dragged it to a hollow in the desert. Here he trussed the poor Copt up in the position in which the predynastic folk were wont to lay out their dead, and trusted to the summer sun to dry the body up sufficiently to pass muster... Returning to the spot six months later, the Arab dealer found the defunct Copt done to a turn, got the body back to his shop and sold it, with the pots, to the British Museum, where the reader can now inspect it whenever he likes."
